title: A Double-Blind-Randomized, Placebo-Controlled Adaptive Design Trial of Nicotinamide in Mild Cognitive Impairment Due to Alzheimer's Disease and Mild Alzheimer's Disease Dementia
description_brief: The purpose of this research study is to test whether nicotinamide, also known as vitamin B3 or niacinamide, taken in high doses, can reduce phosphorylation of tau (the protein that accumulates in neurofibrillary tangles) in people with Mild Cognitive Impairment or mild Alzheimer's disease (AD) dementia.
description_detailed:
Nicotinamide, the amide of nicotinic acid (vitamin B3/niacin), is an oral therapy with a wealth of clinical data in a variety of therapeutic areas, including preliminary data supporting its safety in Alzheimer's disease (AD). Preclinical work in a mouse model that develops both plaques and tangles supports the hypothesis that nicotinamide can act as a histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor to reduce phosphorylation of tau.

The study will implement a group sequential design, incorporating a futility analysis with a go/no-go decision conditional on cerebral spinal fluid CSF biomarker outcomes at 12-months. The primary outcome for the trial is change in p-tau231.

This study timeline includes a screening phase of up to 60 days and treatment phase which is expected to last about 48 weeks and will include 4 study visits.

An additional 12-month treatment and follow-up period is planned, contingent upon a "go" decision based on the primary outcome (CSF p-tau231) or one planned secondary outcome (CSF p-tau181)

participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: 46 participants received at least 1 dose of study drug.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: Mini-Mental State Examination
measures.description: The Mini-Mental State Examination is a brief mental status exam and widely used dementia screening instrument. It evaluates orientation to time and place, memory, attention, language, and visuospatial ability. Range: 0-30; a lower score indicates greater impairment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in P-tau 231
outcomeMeasures.description: Change in key peptide in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from baseline to 48 weeks. Higher phosphorylated tau (p-tau) is associated with a severity of Alzheimer's disease pathology.

outcomeMeasures.title: Columbia-Suicide Severity Rating Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: The Columbia-Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS) captures the occurrence, severity, and frequency of suicide-related thoughts and behaviors during the corresponding assessment period. The scale includes suggested questions to elicit the type of information needed to determine if a suicide-related thought or behavior occurred. The number and proportion of subjects with treatment emergent Suicidal ideation or behavior during the study period of (baseline to week 48) will be reported overall and by study arm. Treatment emergent suicidal ideation or behavior is defined as a "yes" answer at any time during treatment to any one of the questions in the ten suicidal ideation and behavior categories (Categories 1- 10) on the C-SSRS. Self-injurious behavior without suicidal intent, while assessed on the C-SSRS, does not form part of this outcome.

outcomeMeasures.title: ADASCog-13
outcomeMeasures.description: ADAS-Cog13 is a structured scale that evaluates memory (immediate and delayed word recall; immediate word recognition), receptive and expressive language, orientation, ideational praxis (preparing a letter for mailing), constructional praxis (copying figures), and attention (number cancellation). Ratings of spoken language, language comprehension, word finding difficulty, and ability to remember test instructions also are obtained. Range: 0-85; higher scores indicate greater impairment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Activities of Daily Living - Mild Cognitive Impairment
outcomeMeasures.description: The ADCS-ADL-MCI is a measure of patient functional performance in Alzheimer's Disease and Mild Cognitive Impairment trials. The informant-based questionnaire assesses conduct of basic and instrumental Activities of Daily Living (ADLs). A total of 24 ADLs are evaluated. Scores range from 0 to 53, with higher scores representing more maintained function.

outcomeMeasures.title: CDR Sum of Boxes
outcomeMeasures.description: CDR-SB is a composite rating of cognition and everyday function which incorporates both informant input and direct assessment of performance. It assesses through semi-structured interview three cognitive domains (memory, orientation, and judgement/problem solving) and three everyday functional domains (community affairs, home and hobbies, personal care). Level of impairment in each of the six domains is rated from none (score=0) to severe (score=3). The six domain scores are then summed to create the CDR-SB. Range 0-18; higher scores indicate greater impairment.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Adverse event data were collected from signed consent through the participant duration in the study. The specific time period is from consent through the end of the 48 week double-blind trial. Adverse event information will be collected at every planned and unplanned in-person and telephone visit until 7 (for non-serious AEs) or 30 days (for SAEs) after the last day of study participation.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests high‑dose nicotinamide (vitamin B3/niacinamide) with the stated purpose of reducing tau phosphorylation (p‑tau231) in people with MCI or mild AD — i.e., it is intended to act on Alzheimer’s pathology (tau). citeturn0search0

Mechanism / classification: Nicotinamide is a small‑molecule NAD+ precursor and competitive inhibitor of class III histone deacetylases (sirtuins); preclinical work shows it selectively reduces tau phosphorylation (e.g., Thr231) via sirtuin/HDAC‑related pathways. These properties identify it as a disease‑targeted small molecule rather than a biologic or purely symptomatic cognitive enhancer. citeturn0search1turn0search5

Act (extracted trial details): Trial title and description: double‑blind, randomized, placebo‑controlled adaptive trial of nicotinamide in MCI due to AD and mild AD dementia, with primary biomarker endpoint CSF p‑tau231. The investigational agent is nicotinamide (high‑dose oral). citeturn0search0

Trial outcome note (relevant to interpretation): A published phase 2a randomized trial reported that nicotinamide was safe but did not significantly lower CSF p‑tau231 versus placebo after 48 weeks (no biomarker benefit observed). This does not change the intended target classification (pathology‑directed small molecule). citeturn0search0turn0search5

Reflect: Given the intervention (small‑molecule vitamin) and its explicit aim to reduce tau phosphorylation (a core AD pathology), the correct category is 'disease‑targeted small molecule'. There is little ambiguity — the agent is not a biologic (e.g., antibody), not described as only symptomatic/cognitive enhancement without pathology targeting, nor focused on neuropsychiatric symptom management. citeturn0search1turn0search0
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests high‑dose nicotinamide (oral vitamin B3/niacinamide) with the explicit goal of reducing tau phosphorylation (CSF p‑tau231), i.e., it is intended to act on tau pathology rather than amyloid or purely symptomatic targets. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Act: Extracted trial details — randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled phase 2a of nicotinamide (1,500 mg twice daily; 3,000 mg/day) in MCI/mild AD with primary biomarker endpoint CSF p‑tau231; the investigational agent is a small‑molecule vitamin that in preclinical models reduces Thr231‑phospho‑tau via sirtuin (class III HDAC) inhibition. citeturn0search0turn0search3turn0search2

Reflect: Classifying under CADRO, the most specific fit is B) Tau because the intervention is disease‑targeted at tau phosphorylation (not a biologic anti‑tau antibody, nor a symptomatic neurotransmitter agent), and the trial’s stated mechanism and primary biomarker are tau‑focused. Although nicotinamide is a small molecule and has broader metabolic effects (NAD+ related), the trial’s explicit pathology target (p‑tau231) makes B) Tau the correct CADRO category. citeturn0search3turn0search0

Web search results (key sources used): PubMed phase‑2a trial reporting primary endpoint CSF p‑tau231 and that nicotinamide was safe but did not significantly alter AD biomarkers after 48 weeks. citeturn0search0; Preclinical 3xTg‑AD mouse study showing nicotinamide acts via sirtuin inhibition and selectively reduces Thr231‑phospho‑tau. citeturn0search3; ClinicalTrials registry/registry summary for NCT03061474 confirming trial design, dose, and primary biomarker endpoint. citeturn0search2
